text: yesterday I won my second Olympic bronze
medal after Quarry cocktail on ryan's
recent success in Rio one news alert
sparked a lot of criticism on social
media the Chicago Tribune left out her
name in a tweet the newspaper apologized
but this was not the first time the
media coverage of women in the Olympics
has been denounced for sexism language
experts from Cambridge University have
analysed about 160 million words that
share some insight about the way male
and female Olympians are covered here's
one more example this BBC interview with
Andy Murray the first person ever to win
two and then pick tennis gold medals to
defend the singles title I think one of
our for each the researchers found that
the word man is generally used roughly
three times more than the word woman
despite the fact that women make up some
45% of athletes competing I've seen some
of my guy friends try it but they never
land it so they get really upset the
disparity in coverage seems even more
striking given that women receive 58% of
NBC's primetime coverage compared to 41%
for men according to scholars working on
a book about the games words to describe
men include fastest and strongest for
women related words reference their ages
or their marital status
the guy responsible for turning katika
Otsu his wife into a
different smarter so far researchers
have been studying examples from the
past games but the Cambridge team will
soon publish their analysis of the reo
coverage case studies for which have
been called out by the audience almost
on a daily basis
